thread.title: California rescue center overwhelmed with starving seabirds
thread.title_full: California rescue center overwhelmed with starving seabirds - Houston Chronicle

author: chron.com
title: California rescue center overwhelmed with starving seabirds
text:
Photo: Randall Benton, AP Image 1 of / 5 5 In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, intern Julie Wheeler places a common murre into a forced-air drier after an exam at the International Bird Rescue facility in Cordelia, Calif. Across Northern California, malnourished seabirds have been appearing in alarming numbers, some shrunken to little more than feather and bone. Many of the thin-billed species are being brought into the International Bird Rescue Center, which says it is taking in the birds at the highest rates in 18 years. (Randall Benton/The Sacramento Bee via AP)
Photo: Randall Benton, AP In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, intern Julie Wheeler... Image 2 of 5 In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, intern Julie Wheeler removes a common murre from a tank of water for examination at the International Bird Rescue facility in Cordelia, Calif. Across Northern California, malnourished seabirds have been appearing in alarming numbers, some shrunken to little more than feather and bone. Many of the thin-billed species are being brought into the International Bird Rescue Center, which says it is taking in the birds at the highest rates in 18 years. (Randall Benton/The Sacramento Bee via AP)
Photo: Randall Benton, AP In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, intern Julie Wheeler... Image 3 of 5 In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, a cormorant splashes into a pool at the International Bird Rescue facility in Cordelia, Calif. Across Northern California, malnourished seabirds have been appearing in alarming numbers, some shrunken to little more than feather and bone. Many of the thin-billed species are being brought into the International Bird Rescue Center, which says it is taking in the birds at the highest rates in 18 years. (Randall Benton/The Sacramento Bee via AP)
Photo: Randall Benton, AP In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, a cormorant splashes... Image 4 of 5 In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, visiting from their San Pedro facility, Wildlife Center Manager Kelly Berry, is seen at the International Bird Rescue facility in Cordelia, Calif. Across Northern California, malnourished seabirds have been appearing in alarming numbers, some shrunken to little more than feather and bone. Many of the thin-billed species are being brought into the International Bird Rescue Center, which says it is taking in the birds at the highest rates in 18 years. (Randall Benton/The Sacramento Bee via AP)
Photo: Randall Benton, AP In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, visiting from their... Image 5 of 5 In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, volunteers Tom Orr, left, and Nora Chamberlin tend to a tank full of common murres at the International Bird Rescue facility in Cordelia, Calif. Across Northern California, malnourished seabirds have been appearing in alarming numbers, some shrunken to little more than feather and bone. Many of the thin-billed species are being brought into the International Bird Rescue Center, which says it is taking in the birds at the highest rates in 18 years. ((Randall Benton/The Sacramento Bee via AP)
Photo: Randall Benton, AP In this photo taken Thursday, Sept. 24, 2015, volunteers Tom Orr,... California rescue center overwhelmed with starving seabirds 1 / 5 Back to Gallery FAIRFIELD, Calif. (AP) â€” Across Northern California, malnourished seabirds have been appearing in alarming numbers, some shrunken to little more than feather and bone.
The Sacramento Bee reports ( http://bit.ly/1VdrDVp ) Friday that the birds are turning up on beaches from Monterey County to Marin County.
Many of the thin-billed species are being brought into the International Bird Rescue Center , which says it is taking in the birds at the highest rates in 18 years.
The murres' presence is significant to scientists because they're considered a marker species. That means their movements and numbers signal changes in the ocean's food supply, the newspaper reported.
Center spokesman Russ Curtis says more than 250 common murres have been brought into the center in the last month. Curtis says the center usually sees about 10 birds each month in late summer and early fall.
___
Information from: The Sacramento Bee, http://www.sacbee.com
